headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Arrest Warrant for Russian President Vladimir Putin; 5,000-Mile-Wide Mass of Seaweed Headed to Florida; Young People Across the Country Living with Their Parents. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: JOE KAPLAN, KEY WEST RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: It`s thick in the summertime, builds up and smells terrible.

utterances.speaker: LEYLA SANTIAGO, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Joe Kaplan captured these images about a week ago. Massive amounts of seaweed washing up at Smathers Beach, abeach he knows well because he walks it several times a week.

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: I was shocked when I saw it that day where it wasn`t even spring yet. It`s still winter, which is very unusual.

utterances.speaker: CHUANMIN HU, USF COLLEGE OF MARINE SCIENCE
utterances.sentences: And this is about a 5000 miles long.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: Professor Chuanmin, who is one of the leading experts on what many have referred to as a massive blob of seaweed heading to Florida`scoast. (On camera):  Fair to call it a blob?

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: No, we can`t call it a blob, OK.

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: I would never call that a blob. OK.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: OK, why?

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: Because it`s not.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: Satellite images, he says, show it`s not one massive body of seaweed, rather a bunch of patchy clumps traveling from west Africa. It`scalled the Atlantic Sargassum Belt and is considered a natural phenomenon. Right now, it`s twice the width of the U.S. carrying 6 million tons of seaweed and headed to the east coast.

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: In June of this year, it may turn into 20 million tons.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: So let me get this straight, this, what we`re seeing the last month is 6 million tons and it`s going to get bigger?

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: Yes. There`s no way to stop that. This is nature, just like no one can stop a hurricane.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: Should we be worried about that?

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: Nope.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: HU
utterances.sentences: Reason is sargassum is not toxic.

utterances.speaker: SANTIAGO
utterances.sentences: But it smells pretty bad and it`s a nuisance for those trying to keep beaches clean to attract tourists. Just a few years ago, here`s whatit looked like in Mexico, officials in Monroe county, which includes the Florida Keys, have set aside more than $200,000 to clean and remove sargassum from its beaches.

utterances.speaker: CAPTAIN DAN MATTHEWS, MISS CHIEF FISHING CHARTER
utterances.sentences: Seaweed is a mixed blessing. We need it. Seaweed is a nursery for all these large pelagicfish. The negative side to that seaweed is if it comes in the concentrations that are believed, we`re going to see our fishing grounds are going to be completely covered with it. There`s almost no point to fishing because we`re going to be spending the entire day cleaning weed off our lines. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Did you know that as of last summer, half of young adults ages 18 to 29 have roommates that are named mom and dad? Millions of young adults areliving with their parents, and that`s the most since the great depression. Some choose to live with their parents to save money and build for their futures. But many don`t have a choice. The cost of housing is rising. Student loan debt is piling. So here`s CNN`s Correspondent Gabe Cohen who`s been speaking to people across the country who are living at home after college. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: GRACE LEMIRE, LIVES WITH PARENTS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it feels like home.

utterances.speaker: GABE COHEN, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Grace Lemire shows us her Massachusetts home.

utterances.speaker: LEMIRE
utterances.sentences: So this is my childhood bedroom.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Well, her parents` home.

utterances.speaker: LEMIRE
utterances.sentences: This is my mom`s office.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: The 24-year-old moved back after college and hasn`t left, even though she`s now making close to six figures running her own contentmarketing business.

utterances.speaker: LEMIRE
utterances.sentences: I mean, it`s been huge. I`ve been able to completely save an emergency fund. I have been able to put a lot of money onto my studentloans. I have a bigger down payment for a future home. Those are things that are important to me and make living at home make more sense for me.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: She posts about it on TikTok.

utterances.speaker: LEMIRE
utterances.sentences: But have you seen the rent prices out there?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: And she`s not alone.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN HOWLETT, LIVES WITH PARENTS
utterances.sentences: Living by yourself is almost impossible.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Millions of young adults moved home during the pandemic, and many haven`t left.

utterances.speaker: EMILY STONE, LIVES WITH PARENTS
utterances.sentences: It`s something that I used to be almost like, embarrassed or ashamed of, but not anymore.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: As of last summer, 50% of adults 18 to 29 years old were living with their parents, according to Pew, down just slightly from 52% at thepeak of the pandemic, the most since the Great Depression.

utterances.speaker: LEMIRE
utterances.sentences: I would say most of my friends are actually living at home with their parents.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Housing costs are a key reason. The average rent nationwide, nearly $2,000 is 26% higher than at the start of COVID and only rising amid thishigh inflation.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE BRUNIK, LIVES WITH PARENTS
utterances.sentences: I can`t be financially stable if I want to go out and live on my own.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: 23-year-old Christine Brunilk has lived with her parents in a Minnesota suburb since finishing college. Renting her own place, she says,could cost half her marketing salary.

utterances.speaker: BRUNIK
utterances.sentences: I feel kind of, like in a stagnant position.COHEN (on camera):  What`s your plan as of now?

utterances.speaker: BRUNIK
utterances.sentences: I`m hoping to move out in August, but again, that depends if I find roommates.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Then there`s student loan debt.

utterances.speaker: JON WILLIAMS, LIVES WITH PARENTS
utterances.sentences: The goal is to just clear that out as quickly as I can.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: 26-year-old Jon Williams, a pharmacist in Michigan, moved into his parents basement after finishing grad school with $180,000 of student debt,he says.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It has been a very minimalist lifestyle. I`ve saved over 80% of my net income.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: When do you think you`ll be able to clear your student debt?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Probably late fall. I`m about three quarters of the way through it right now.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Are you getting antsy?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I am getting slightly antsy. I do feel like 2023 would probably be a good year for me to move out.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Many Americans don`t like this trend, 36% say that more young adults living with parents is bad for society, while 6% say it`s good.According to Pew Research.

utterances.speaker: LEMIRE
utterances.sentences: I`ve been called a fraud and a freeloader.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Grace`s mom had a different take.NANCY LEMIRE, GRACE`S MOTHER:  If she`s in a better position, then that gives us peace of mind. And when we get older, if we need help, she`ll be in a better position to help us, right? (END VIDEOTAPE)
